resources.string: Click the card to see the answer
Click the answer to see the question again
In some terrestrial arthropods, tube that carries air directly to the cells
Muscular organ that pumps blood to all parts of the body
One of pair of spongy , saclike organs where gas exchange occurs
Control center for the vertebrate body
Opening in the center of the iris

Red blood cells, or erythrocytes, are the most common type of blood cell. Their primary function is to transport oxygen from the lungs to the bodys tissues and carbon dioxide from the tissues back to the lungs for exhalation.
White blood cells, also known as leukocytes, are a vital part of the immune system. They help the body fight infection and foreign invaders, such as bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens.

Arterioles are small blood vessels that branch out from arteries and lead to capillaries. The arteriole wall consists of three layers: the tunica intima (inner layer), tunica media (middle layer), and tunica externa (outer layer). These walls are muscular and can contract or dilate to regulate blood flow and blood pressure.
The cell nucleus and organelles reside inside the cell body.
Myelinated axons increase the speed of action potentials down the nerve and insulate the fibers to prevent cross talk.
Several dendrites receive signals from other neurons. If enough signals reach the threshold necessary, an axon potential is initiated and travels down the axon.
Οligodendroglial cells are responsible for the synthesis and maintenance of myelin, whereas Schwann cells subserve this role in the peripheral nervous system (PNS).
Axon terminals are the ends of axons which transmit messages to other cells via use of neurotransmitters at synapses

The heart is a muscular organ about the size of a fist, located just behind and slightly left of the breastbone. The heart pumps blood through the network of arteries and veins called the cardiovascular system.
Lets oxygen-rich blood from your lungs pass from the left atrium into the left ventricle.
Opens the way for oxygen-rich blood to pass from the left ventricle into the aorta, your body’s largest artery.
Known as the heart strings, are cord-like tendons that connect the papillary muscles to the tricuspid valve and the bicuspid valve in the heart.
Regulates blood flow between the right atrium and right ventricle.
Controls blood flow from the right ventricle into the pulmonary arteries, which carry blood to your lungs to pick up oxygen.

The right upper chamber of the heart. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the body through the vena cava and pumps it into the right ventricle which then sends it to the lungs to be oxygenated.
The lower right chamber of the heart that receives deoxygenated blood from the right atrium and pumps it under low pressure into the lungs via the pulmonary artery.
The left lower chamber of the heart that receives blood from the left atrium and pumps it out under high pressure through the aorta to the body.
The upper left chamber of the heart. The left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs and pumps it down into the left ventricle which delivers it to the body.

The frontal lobes are important for voluntary movement, expressive language and for managing higher level executive functions. Executive functions refer to a collection of cognitive skills including the capacity to plan, organize, initiate, self-monitor and control one’s responses in order to achieve a goal.

The parietal lobes can be divided into two functional regions. One involves sensation and perception and the other is concerned with integrating sensory input, primarily with the visual system. The first function integrates sensory information to form a single perception (cognition).

Most commonly associated with processing auditory information and with the encoding of memory. The temporal lobes are also believed to play an important role in processing affect/emotions, language, and certain aspects of visual perception.

The brainstem has many basic functions, including regulation of heart rate, breathing, sleeping, and eating. It also plays a role in conduction. All information relayed from the body to the cerebrum and cerebellum and vice versa must traverse the brainstem.
The occipital lobe is the part of the human brain responsible for interpreting information from the eyes and turning it into the world as a person sees it.
The iris is a flat and ring-shaped membrane, it is Made of densely pigmented posterior double epithelium. This structure Serves as the “diaphragm” of the eye.

Ciliary body is a circular structure that extends from the iris (the colored part of the eye). Ciliary Body is divided into two parts : a- The first one is the Ciliary muscle. b- The second one represents Ciliary Processes

The sclera is the white part of the eye that surrounds the cornea. In fact, the sclera forms more than 80 percent of the surface area of the eyeball, extending from the cornea all the way to the optic nerve, which exits the back of the eye. Only a small portion of the anterior sclera is visible.

Trachea (TRAY-kee-uh) is a long, U-shaped tube that connects your larynx (voice box) to your lungs. The trachea is often called the windpipe. Its a key part of your respiratory system. When you breathe in, air travels from your nose or mouth through your larynx
Bronchi have two main (or primary, or first) parts: Right main bronchus is a short, wide air passageway into your right lung. Left main bronchus is a narrow, long passageway into your left lung.

The cricoid cartilage is a hyaline cartilage ring which fully encircles the trachea and composes the inferior-most boundary of the laryngeal skeleton. The term “cricoid,” (Greek, krikos meaning “ring-shaped”) refers to the signet-ring resemblance of the cricoid cartilage.

Your ribcage is assembled from three types of bone - your sternum, 12 pairs of ribs and 12 thoracic vertebrae. All of your ribs attach to your spine, but only the top seven pairs connect to your sternum. These are known as true ribs and they are connected to your sternum by strips of cartilage.

cervical spine is the neck region of your spinal column or backbone. It consists of your first seven bones (C1-C7). Other structures in or around your cervical spine are your intervertebral disks, spinal cord and nerves, muscles, tendons and ligaments.

The sternum is a partially T-shaped vertical bone that forms the anterior portion of the chest wall centrally. The sternum is divided anatomically into three segments: manubrium, body, and xiphoid process. The sternum connects the ribs via the costal cartilages forming the anterior rib cage
Patient with longstanding history of intermittent headache. What does the image show?
History of head injury. Patient unconscious. Which statement is true?
There is no evidence of mass effect
Changing window settings would help clarify the diagnosis
A history of anticoagulation is irrelevant in this setting
Patient with a sudden onset of hemianopia. What does this pre-contrast CT brain image demonstrate?
Which description most accurately describes the findings on these two images?
Increased density consistent with a subdural collection
Multiple areas of enhancement due to metastases
Areas of abnormally low density surrounded by enhancement post IV-contrast
Increased density consistent with an acute primary intracerebral haemorrhage
Patient with history of recent head injury. What does this scan show?
Which finding is present on this image?
Which finding is present on this detail image of the left lung?
20 year old female with high temperature and cough. Which answer best describes the appearance?
Image inadequate due to patient rotation
Cough, weight loss and finger clubbing. Which statement is true?
The image is diagnostic of lung cancer
The image is diagnostic of pneumonia
Blunting of the costophrenic angles is due to pleural effusions
Fall onto face. Painful left cheek area. OM and OM-30 views.
Inversion injury to ankle. Unable to bear weight. AP and lateral views.
Fall on outstretched hand. Pain and restricted shoulder abduction. 2 AP clavicle views.
Fall with direct trauma to knee. Pain, swelling and reduced knee movement. AP and horizontal beam lateral views.
Flexion/extension injury to neck. Single open-mouth odontoid peg views (other views were normal).
Punch injury to hand. DP and Oblique views.
Fall on shoulder. Pain and reduced range of movement. AP and Axial views.
Fall on outstretched hand. Clavicle pain and tenderness. 2 AP views.
Fall on outstretched hand. Painful and tender forearm. AP and Lateral views.
Injury to elbow when intoxicated. Wound to skin. AP and Lateral views.
Twisted ankle. Pain medially and laterally. AP and lateral views.
Twisting injury. Painful foot. DP and oblique views.
Patient confused. Fall. Pain in hip. AP view of the pelvis.
Hyperextension injury to knee. Pain and tenderness medially. AP and lateral views.
Twisting injury to ankle. Pain and tenderness. Unable to walk. Single AP view (other views were normal).
Largest veins in the body, formed from the consecutive merging of smaller veins. Includes the superior (upper) and inferior (lower) vena cava.
Two arteries (left and right) branching off of the end of the abdominal aorta near the ilium. Supplies oxygenated blood to the rectum, bladder, reproductive organs, legs, and feet.
The portion of the aorta occurring after the aortic arch that is made up of the thoracic (in the thorax of the body) and abdominal (in the abdominal cavity of the body) aorta.
A branching portion of the aorta that is shaped like an upside-down U. Responsible for supplying the arms, neck, head, and brain with oxygenated blood.
Two arteries (left and right) that carry oxygenated blood to the heart muscle. When blocked due to plaque build-up, can lead to a heart attack.
The largest artery found in the body which functions in carrying blood away from the heart from the left ventricle to the rest of the body.
A large artery that fills with deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle of the heart following the opening of the pulmonary semilunar valve.Connects to the left and right pulmonary arteries.
Dendrites are extensions leading toward cell body that receives signal from other neurons and send them to the cell body.
Part of neuron that holds the nucleus as well as other organelles, also called the soma.
Contains the genetic material of the neuron.
A long strand attached to the cell body. Conducts nerve impulses away from the cell body toward other neurons or effectors.
A lipid layer around the axon. It carries the message to one of these lipids to another, making transporting an impulse efficient.
Neurons transmit messages in the form of electrochemical impulses called an action potential.
This consists of the brain and spinal cord. This is the ultimate control center for all human behavior.
Carries deoxygentated blood from the heart to the lungs.
Receives oxygen-rich blood from the lungs through the four pulmonary veins.
The two valves that blood coming from the body passes.
Tricuspid valve and the pulmonary semilunar valve.
The two valves that blood coming from the lungs passes.
Mitral (bicuspid) valve and the aortic semilunar valve.
The primary pumping chambers of the heart.
Blood is forced into this area when the ventricle is filled.
Named for the three flaps that separate the right atrium and right ventricle.
Identify the system of the brain that controls emotion and motivation.
Name the 4 parts of the brain involved in basic functions.
Brainstem, Thalamus, Reticular Formation and Cerebellum.
Identify the primary function of the Occipital Lobe.
Identify the primary functions of the Parietal Lobe.
Identify the primary function of the Temporal Lobe.
What is the difference between a gyrus and a sulcus?
A gyrus is a bump in the brain, a sulcus is a groove.
Identify the primary function of the Thalamus.
Forwards information from the senses to other parts of the brain.
The outermost lens of the eye that focuses light into the inner eye and protects it from harmful matter.
The light sensitive layer within the eye that converts images into electrical signals.
The hole located in the iris that changes size to allow different amounts of light into the inner eye.
The colorful structure of the eye that changes the shape of the pupil to allow for different amounts of light to enter the inner eye.
A muscle that controls the shape of the lens to better focus the light onto the retina of the inner eye.
The transparent orb within the eye that refracts light to the retina of the eye.
The nerve at the back of the eye that transports electric signals to the brain.
Prevents entry of liquids or solid food through glottis so that food/ liquid would not enter lungs.
Tough flexible tube, protects airway, also prevent collapse or expansion of airway as pressure change in respiratory system. Transports air down the vertebra towards the lungs.
Persistent slowing of airflow during breathing.
An objective measurement of lung function.
Airway passages that conduct air into the lungs (have cartilage).
Branches of the bronchi, the first passageways by which the air passes through the nose or mouth into the air sacs of the lungs (no cartilage).
The throat. A chamber shared by the digestive and respiratory systems, where materials entering the digestive tract pass through.
The pyramidal space below the shoulder joint - provides passage for the vessels and nerves going to and from the upper limb.
At which anatomical point does the axillary artery begin?
The lateral border of the 1st rib.
The axillary artery continues beyond the axilla as which vessel?
Name the roots of the brachial plexus?
The site of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (2–3cm above the clavicle).
Name the muscles in the superficial group of the anterior forearm.
Pronator teres, Flexor carpi radialis, Palmaris longus and Flexor carpi ulnaris.
What are the superficial muscles of the anterior forearm attached to?
The medial epicondyle of the humerus by the common flexor tenson.
Lungs are the pair of spongy, pinkish-gray organs in our chest. When we inhale (breathe in), air enters our lungs and oxygen from that air moves to our blood.
The heart is a vital organ. It is a muscle that pumps blood to all parts of human body. The blood pumped by the heart provides the human body with the oxygen and nutrients it needs to function.
It is a key part of our respiratory system. When we breathe in, air travels from our nose or mouth through our larynx. It then passes through our trachea to our bronchi.
The brain is a complex organ that controls thought, memory, emotion, touch, motor skills, vision, breathing, temperature, hunger and every process that regulates our body.
The round opening in the center of the iris.
The stomach is an important organ and the most dilated portion of the digestive system. The esophagus precedes it, and the small intestine follows.
The pancreas has dual roles, it is an organ of the digestive system and of the endocrine system.
